prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm continuum and CO(1-0) imaging in NGC 3125
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will map 3mm continuum to determine the free-free flux and distribution. At the same time we will detect CO(1-0) to get a line flux and linewidth. These will be used to compare to 870 micron continuum and line to compare dust and gas tracers of gas mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The linewidths of individual clouds will be about 10km/s FWHM. We have chosen spectral averaging to adequately sample and allow determination of line centroids.

We are trying to isolate GMC/cluster interactions, so the smaller the better. Here 0.3" =20 pc.
The largest angular scale is determined by the fact that we want to map individual GMCs, which will be less than 100 pc. They will be warmer and denser than diffuse CO clouds, so will be distinct. Our largest structures will be less than 5" easily.

Our main goal is getting a good continuum map at 3mm to measure free-free flux and distribution. We expect a free-free flux of about 3-4 mJy, but spread over the beam, so peaks will be about ten times less, 300 mJy. We can smooth if necessary to improve S/N, since 0.3" is 20 pc. But the HII region should be smaller than this.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 870 micron continuum and CO(3-2) Imaging in NGC 7714
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To map the 870 micron continuum and CO(3-2), to measure the dust content and CO(3-2). We will compare the CO indicators of gas mass to the dust mass. We need 3mm to determine the free-free contribution to the submm continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We're after individual GMCs. One of the goals is to get a good linewidth. Thus we need resolutions smaller than 10km/s.

W're trying to isolate emission from individual star-forming regions. At 30 Mpc, 0.3" ~45 pc, which should be dominated by a forming SSC and its molecular cloud.
We are trying to detect warm, dense, star-forming clouds and not cooler, quiescent disk clouds. We are not interested in the diffuse disk. Hence any cloud we wish to detect is probably smaller than 1". We do not need the compact array.

The sensitivity is driven by the continuum. We expect about 0.5 mJy of dust and the same for free-free in individual beams. We will be subtracting off the 3mm free-free to get the dust component at 870 microns so we need to consider S/N on the dust alone.
The sensitivity to CO(3-2) is sufficient to detect and determine a linewidth, which is one of our goals. At this resolution the emission should fill the bean and be ~1K brightness or more. We do not spectrally smooth too much because if the line is bright, as we expect, we can get kinematics such as linewidths and centroids. Individual clouds will have linewidths 5-10 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 870 micron continuum and CO(3-2) Imaging in NGC 1156
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The 870 micron continuum can give the dust emission when the 3mm free-free contribution has been subtracted off. Simultaneously we can observe CO(3-2). Together these will give us an idea of the chemical and energetic feedback into GMCs associated with SSC formation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We wish to resolve the lines, which will be about 10km/s FWHM for an individual GMC, to get centroids and linewidths. So we spectral average a little.

We choose 0.5" for this relatively nearby (7.5 Mpc) galaxy. It will give a resolution of 18pc on the galaxy, sufficient to isolate the GMC associated with the large HII region/cluster.
Since we are only interested in detecting individual GMCs, we do not need sensitivity to scales larger than 5". The CO(3-2) will be sensitive to warmer denser clouds so this should not be as much of an issue as for 1-0.

We may marginally resolve the HII region, since the beam is 18pc and the existing VLA image shows a little structure. The expected free-free flux is about 1.3 mJy, with dust we estimate it could be double that. We thus have 10:1 S/N on dust or free-free alone, since we will be subtracting off the 3mm.
The line sensitivity that comes with this continuum sensitivity is adequate for easily detecting the CO(3-2) line, if it is bright, as we expect based on NGC5253. We are interested in the line kinematics so we don't want to spectral average too much.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 870 micron continuum and CO(3-2) Imaging in NGC 3125
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The 870 micron continuum can give the dust emission when the 3mm free-free contribution has been subtracted off. Simultaneously we can observe CO(3-2). Together these will give us an idea of the chemical and energetic feedback into GMCs associated with star formation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We wish to resolve the GMC lines, which are about 10km/s FWHM, to get good centroids and kinematics. We can spectral average if needed.

We wish to resolve individual GMCs. 0.3" gives 20 pc resolution.
We are not interested in mapping large scale structure. We aim to detect warm clouds associated with a massive cluster. These structures will be less than 50 pc in size, easily. 5"- 300 pc so these will easily be less than 5".

The continuum could be as much as 8 mJy total emission with dust. We need to separate free-free and dust by subtracting off the 3mm continuum to get the dust contribution. If this source is like NGC 5253, it will be about half free-free and half dust. The observed 3cm flux is about 4mJy, total, in agreement with our estimate, in a couple of sources (Aversa et al. 2011). This will be resolved by this beam so we need to achieve a S/N in dust alone of about 4mJy/10 = 400 microJy structures in the individual beams, about 20 pc.
If the CO(3-2) is bright, as we expect, then the line could be easily detected. We choose not to spectral average too much, because we want good sampling to determine line centroids and widths.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to image local star forming clouds in 870 micron continua to study their dust contents, while simultaneously observing them in CO(3-2). Comparison with 3mm maps will allow for measurements of dust and gas masses, along with star formation efficiencies.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, California at Los Angeles, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, California at Los Angeles, University of
